Great King!
As for the hard and solid nature of the external earth element, at that time in the world, the palace of BrahmÄ, the first to be built, was made of great treasures.
Then the palaces of the ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin gods were born, all made of the seven treasures.
Great King!
If the hard and solid nature of the earth element did not arise, where did it come from?
It further formed the great earth, 84,000 yojanas thick and 60,000 yojanas wide.
It further gave rise to the CakravÄá¸a and MahÄcakravÄá¸a mountains, firmly abiding as one with vajra.

In this way, the trichiliocosm is gradually formed, firm and stable.
If the earth element did not arise with a solid nature, from what would it come?
Great King!
Moreover, when this world is about to be destroyed, it may be burned by fire, flooded by water, or blown away by wind.
When this great earth is burned by fire, it is like burning ghee and oil, with flames spreading everywhere, until even the ashes and embers are no longer visible.
If it is flooded by water, it is like throwing salt into water, immediately dissolving and disappearing.
If it is blown by the Vairambha wind, this trichiliocosm will be completely destroyed, leaving nothing behind.
Great King!

This external earth element, when arising, is empty, and when ceasing, is also empty. It is empty by its very nature, having no male characteristics and no female characteristics, but is only indicated by verbal expressions.
In this way, the earth element and the nature of the earth element are both unobtainable. One should truly and correctly understand this with wisdom.
What is the internal water element?
It refers to the moisture and so forth that are internally appropriated by this body.
What are they?
Namely, saliva, sweat, mucus, phlegm, fat, marrow, pus, blood, urine, and feces - these are the internal water element.
Great King!

When one suddenly sees a loved one and tears flow from the eyes, or when one is afflicted by suffering and tears flow, or when one hears the profound Dharma with faith and tears flow, or when one is blown by cold wind and tears flow, from where does this water element come?
When the characteristics of water dry up, where does it go?

Moreover, when this realm is destroyed, black clouds rise everywhere in thirty-two layers, covering the trichiliocosm, and torrential rain pours from the sky, with drops as large as elephants, pouring day and night without interruption.
In this way, for a period of five intermediate kalpas, the water accumulates and fills up to the Brahma world.
Great King!
From where does this great water element come?
Moreover, when this world is about to be destroyed, two suns appear. When two suns appear, the small rivers and springs all dry up.
When three suns appear, even the four rivers flowing out of Lake Anavatapta dry up.
When four suns appear, the water in the great ocean decreases by one yojana, or two or three, gradually decreasing to ten yojanas, or twenty yojanas, and so on, drying up to eighty yojanas.
Some water remains, either one tÄla tree deep, or deep enough to reach the chest, or deep like a cow's hoofprint, down to a little water one finger-width deep.
At that time, the water in the great ocean is completely dried up, completely gone without remainder.
Great King!

The characteristics of this water element, when arising, do not come from anywhere, and when ceasing, do not go anywhere. When arising, it is originally empty, and when ceasing, it is also empty. Because its intrinsic nature is empty, there are no male characteristics and no female characteristics, but are only revealed by verbal expressions.
In this way, the water element and the nature of the water element are both unobtainable.
What is the internal fire element?
It refers to all that is appropriated and possessed in this body, such as the nature of warmth and so forth.
What is that again?
It refers to warmth, heat, digestion of food and drink, transformation and decay, and bringing about comfort. That which enters the category of heat is called the internal fire element.
What is the external fire element?
It refers to the characteristics of warmth and heat that are not appropriated.
If a person in the wilderness seeks for the conditions of fire, using mugwort, cow dung, or cotton to produce fire, it may burn grass, trees, mountains, forests, villages, and other places.
Great King!
Thus, the fire element, when arising, does not come from anywhere, and when ceasing, does not go anywhere, because from the very beginning it is naturally devoid of intrinsic nature.
What is the internal wind element?
It is the nature of lightness and movement.
What is that?

It is the internal wind that sometimes moves upwards, sometimes moves downwards, sometimes abides in the abdomen, sometimes in the sides or back, sometimes causes rashes, sometimes forms into lumps, sometimes splits like a knife, sometimes pricks like a needle, and the in- and out-breaths that pervade the limbs of the body.
The external wind element refers to the wind that comes from the four directions, sometimes tight like an arrow, sometimes sharp like a blade.
If it arises violently, it can uproot trees, topple mountains, and split mountain peaks;
if it arises subtly, it can flutter one's clothes and move a tÄla tree. It is called the external wind element, the rest as explained above.
What is the internal space element?
It refers to the skin, flesh, blood, and so forth within this body, which are manifest, growing, and free from obstruction.
What is that?
Namely, if the eye sockets, ear holes, mouth, throat, and the passage for swallowing food and drink lead to the passage for flavor, it passes through the intestines and stomach and comes out.

If at that time karmic conditions lead to the production of the six sense bases, and after the production of the sense bases they surround the space element, this is called being counted as the internal space element.
But where does that space element come from?
If again what is manifested externally as unobstructed nature is called the external space element.
Great King!
If form changes and decays, all is empty.
Why is it so?
Because this space element is originally inexhaustible, it abides stably and immovable, just like nirvana, pervading everywhere without obstruction.
Great King!
It is like a person who digs a pond or well on a high plain.
What do you think?
Where does the empty appearance in that pond or well come from?
The king said:
It comes from nowhere.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
Suppose someone were to fill it with earth again. What do you think?
Where would the emptiness go?
The king said:
Emptiness does not go anywhere.
Why is it so?
This realm of space has no coming or going, does not abide in male characteristics, and does not abide in female characteristics.
Great King!
The external realm of space is originally unmoving.
Why is it so?
Because its intrinsic nature is detached, one can truly understand it with right wisdom.
Furthermore, Great King!
What is the realm of consciousness?
It refers to the eye faculty as the dominant factor, each separately perceiving apparent colors, shapes, and indicative forms, called the eye-consciousness realm.
If the six faculties are the dominant factor, each separately establishes the six sense objects, called the six consciousness realms.
Moreover, this realm of consciousness does not cling to the faculties, does not abide in the sense objects, is neither internal nor external, nor in between the two.
However, this realm of consciousness, having cognized each and every thing, immediately ceases. When arising, it does not come from anywhere, and when ceasing, it does not go anywhere.
Great King!

When consciousness arises, it is empty, and when it ceases, it is also empty. Because its intrinsic nature is empty, it does not abide in the male form nor is it the female form, but is only revealed by verbal expression.
In this way, the realm of consciousness and the nature of consciousness are both unobtainable. One is able to understand this through the correct wisdom of reality.
Great King!
What is the eye faculty?
It is the pure form created by the four great elements: the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the wind element.
If the earth element is pure, then the eye faculty is pure. If the water, fire, and wind elements are pure, then the eye faculty is pure.
Why is this?
Because of the purity of the earth element, the eye faculty is able to arise, yet within this, there is not a single dharma that can be obtained.
In this way, up to because of the purity of the wind element, the eye faculty is able to arise, yet within this, there is not a single dharma that can be obtained.
Why is this?
Because there is no master or controller, and because there is no creation, it is like nirvana, pure by nature.
Great King!
In this way, each of the sense faculties is sought but cannot be found.
Why is this?
Because the earth element is empty, the earth element is pure, and so on up to because the wind element is empty, the wind element is pure.

If the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is originally empty, then what purity is there in those elements? There is also no anger or dispute. Whether pure or disputed, both cannot be obtained. Then what form is there to be seen?

One should know that because the sense faculty of the eye is ultimately empty, its intrinsic nature is also empty. The past and future cannot be obtained, and what is created in the future cannot be obtained either.
Why is this?
Because the intrinsic nature is detached.
If the intrinsic nature does not exist, then there is no male form and no female form. How can there be affection?
If affection arises, it is the realm of Mara. If there is no affection, it is the realm of the Buddha.
Why is this?
If there is no delight, one will be able to distance oneself from all phenomena.
Your Majesty!
What is the domain of the ears?
It refers to the pure form created by the four great elements.
Up to this, Your Majesty!
The liberation of all phenomena definitely manifests in accordance with the emptiness of the dharma realm, which cannot be designated, cannot be revealed, cannot be recorded, and has no expectations.
Your Majesty!
The various faculties each delight in their objects. When the eyes encounter form, they give rise to delight. Therefore, form is said to be the domain of the eyes.

Moreover, when the eye faculty encounters a form object, it observes three kinds of characteristics. When encountering a lovable form, it gives rise to a greedy thought; when encountering a dislikable form, it gives rise to an angry thought; when encountering a form that is neither lovable nor hateful, it gives rise to a thought of indifference.

In the same way, up to the mind being attached to the dharma realm as the object of the mind. If the mind-realm encounters a desirable form, it gives rise to extreme attachment and is dragged by it, producing the practice of greed. An undesirable form gives rise to the practice of anger. Regarding the desirable and undesirable, it produces the practice of delusion.
In the same way, the three kinds of objects such as sound, etc., should be explained according to the previous [example].
Great King!
You should know that the faculties are like an illusion, and the objects are like a dream. It is like a person who, in a dream, enjoys himself with various beautiful women.
Great King!
What do you think?
After that person has awakened from the dream, does the recollection of the beautiful women and enjoyment in the dream really exist or not?
The king said:
No, World-Honored One!
Great King!
What do you think?
Is the person who grasps the dream as real a wise one or not?
No, World-Honored One!

When foolish ordinary beings see forms with the eyes, their minds give rise to fondness and further attachment. They are dragged along by them and create karmic actions out of craving, with three kinds of physical actions, four kinds of verbal actions, and three kinds of mental actions. As soon as they are created, they cease and do not abide in the east, south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, above or below.
At the end of death, when the life faculty ceases, one's own karmic retribution all appears before one, just like remembering the events in a dream upon waking.
Great King!

Consciousness is the main factor, and karma is the condition. These two factors cause the initial consciousness to arise, leading to rebirth in the hells, as an animal, in the realm of Yama, as an asura, as a human, or as a god.
The initial consciousness is called name, and each receives its corresponding retribution. The continuum of the class of consciousnesses of the same kind continues to evolve.
The final cessation of consciousness is called the aggregate at death, and the initial arising of consciousness is called the aggregate at birth.
Great King, you should know that there is no dharma whatsoever that goes from this world to the next world.
Why is this?
Because its nature is to arise and cease.
Great King!
When the body consciousness arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere;
when that karma arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere;
when the initial consciousness arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere.
Why is this?
Because it is devoid of intrinsic nature.

In this way, one understands that the body consciousness and body consciousness are empty, that one's own karma and one's own karma are empty, that the initial consciousness and initial consciousness are empty, that if extinguished, extinction is empty, and that if born, birth is empty. One understands that karmic bondage has no doer and no experiencer, but is merely a conceptual designation.

Up to this, Great King!
In this Dharma, you should settle your mind well and think like this:

How can I be the eyes for humans and gods, a great lamp and torch providing illumination, a boatman leading to the other shore, a great caravan leader leading to the place of treasures, to liberate those who are not yet liberated, to bring peace to those who are not yet at peace, and to attain nirvana for those who have not yet attained nirvana?
Great King, you should know that the faculties are like an illusion, and the objects are like a dream. Ordinary beings are bound to them without ever being satisfied.

In the past, countless eons ago, there was a wheel-turning king named Immeasurable Renown, whose majestic virtue and fame were renowned and wealthy, and he ruled the four continents alone as the supreme one. He could enjoy whatever he desired, and all the forests and trees were always in bloom and bearing fruit.

At that time, the people of the world were at peace and had no troubles. Moreover, he was able to rain down various wonderful fragrances, gold, silver, precious treasures, and various necessities, and all their needs were fully met.
Suddenly one time, he ascended to the Heaven of the Thirty-three, and the Lord of the Heaven of the Thirty-three divided his seat and ordered him to sit.
Greed and desire were insatiable and wanted to encroach on his position. Having had this thought, he immediately fell down, and the ministers surrounded him and all saw it.
It was like fresh butter placed in hot sand, unable to last long, about to end its life.
At that time there was a king named RÄma, who, having seen this, said:
How should I in the world speak well of this matter?

Therefore, great king!
The faculties are like an illusion, and the objects are like a dream. You should comfort your mind and do not give rise to trust and obedience.
The body is like a mirage, with no inherent nature. Form, feeling, perception, and mental formations are also like this, with no true inherent nature.
